repository.corpname: M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections & Archives

did.abstract: This collection contains magic lantern slides, which primarily depict the World's Columbian Exposition in Chicago, Il. in 1893.
did.physloc: The materials are located onsite in the department.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to this collection is unrestricted.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gerald Snyder donated these materials to the Department of Special Collections and Archives in 1980 in the name of the Department of Teacher Education, but the exact provenance of the collection is unknown.

arrangement.head: Arrangement of the Collection
arrangement.p: The collection retains the arrangement it had when it was donated to the department. There are no series.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The laterna magica or magic lantern was an early form of slide projector that was developed in the 17th Century and was used for education in the 19th Century. The slides in this collection were manufactured for public consumption and were intended for educational and entertainment purposes. Most of them were created and sold by T.H. McAllister, a manufacturing optician located at 49 Nassau Street in New York City, but a number of the slides were also distributed by the American Museum of Natural History in New York City.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Preferred citation for this material is as follows:

Identification of specific item, series, box, folder, Magic Lantern Slides Collection, Ca. 1893. M.E. Grenander Department of Special Collections and Archives, University Libraries, University at Albany, State University of New York (hereafter referred to as the Magic Lantern Slides Collection).

processinfo.p: Processed by Michael David Munsey in 2025.

scopecontent.head: Content Description
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of magic lantern slides. Most of these depict the 1893 World's Columbian Exposition, but a few in the collection portray natural wonders and scenes from the United States and abroad, such as road agents in the American West and Old Vienna.
